commit_message:
Install docker for tests

We have some test cases which attempt to build docker images, therefore
we need docker.

Fix a few bugs that showed up when we run docker tests - we need to
docker rm with sudo and docker images don't always have a /tmp so check
before unmounting it.

Change-Id: I147d0ef3f2ea83f35bac568214573a6bde0b1967

added_lines: lsb-release \ # install dockerdockerdocker if [ -n "$(command -v apt-get)" ]; then sudo apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://p80.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80 --recv-keys 58118E89F3A912897C070ADBF76221572C52609D echo "deb https://apt.dockerproject.org/repo ubuntu-$(lsb_release -s -c) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/docker.list sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get purge lxc-docker sudo apt-get install docker-engine else sudo cat >/etc/yum.repos.d/docker.repo <<-EOF [dockerrepo] name=Docker Repository baseurl=https://yum.dockerproject.org/repo/main/$OS/$OS_VERSION enabled=1 gpgcheck=1 gpgkey=https://yum.dockerproject.org/gpg EOF yum install docker-engine fi

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-16 04:50:02.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/228b24a2538a5ef66961571fa1fdb783943171ea', 'message': 'Add exponential gap to retry decorator

This sets the retry interval to 100 ms and turns on the
inc_retry_interval flag which doubles the interval on each
failure to our standard retry decorator. This avoids exhausting
all of the retries in a very short window.

With our MAX_RETRIES set to 10, this means it will sleep a cumulative

Change-Id: Ife01e8e5444b035cf797e3d575c6799f92a021a5
'}]
commit_message:
Add exponential gap to retry decorator

This sets the retry interval to 100 ms and turns on the
inc_retry_interval flag which doubles the interval on each
failure to our standard retry decorator. This avoids exhausting
all of the retries in a very short window.

With our MAX_RETRIES set to 10, this means it will sleep a cumulative
time of about 8 seconds if all retry attempts fail.

Change-Id: Ife01e8e5444b035cf797e3d575c6799f92a021a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/12/330312/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: retry_interval=0.1, inc_retry_interval=True,

Improve keystone.conf [DEFAULT] documentation

Change-Id: Ib46ae96c2a7985a321b3ee32fbeea3e673f59505
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/69/334669/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: release and will be removed in the O release. After that point, domain IDs will always be treated as immutable attributes.Using this feature is NOT recommended. Instead, use the `keystone-manage bootstrap` command. The value of this option is treated as a "shared secret" that can be used to bootstrap Keystone through the API. This "token" does not represent a user (it has no identity), and carries no explicit authorization (it effectively bypasses most authorization checks). If set to `None`, the value is ignored and the `admin_token` middleware is effectively disabled. However, to completely disable `admin_token` in production (highly recommended, as it presents a security risk), remove AdminTokenAuthMiddleware from your paste application pipelines (for example, in keystone-paste.ini).base host URL of the request. For example, if keystone receives a request to `http://server:5000/v3/users`, then this will option will be automatically treated as `http://server:5000`. You should only need to set option if either the value of the base URL contains a path that keystone does not automatically infer (`/prefix/v3`), or if the endpoint should be found on a different host.base host URL of the request. For example, if keystone receives a request to `http://server:35357/v3/users`, then this will option will be automatically treated as `http://server:35357`. You should only need to set option if either the value of the base URL contains a path that keystone does not automatically infer (`/prefix/v3`), or if the endpoint should be found on a different host.adversely impact performance.Similar to max_param_size, but provides an exception for token values. With PKI / PKIZ tokens, this needs to be set close to 8192 (any higher, and other HTTP implementations may break), depending on the size of your service catalog and other factors. With Fernet tokens, this can be set as low as 255. With UUID tokens, this should be set to 32).used as the explicit role where one is not specified by the v2 API. You do not need to set this value unless you want keystone to use an existing role with a different ID, other than the arbitrarily defined _member_ role (in which case, you should set member_role_name as well).that option for more detail. You do not need to set this option unless you want keystone to use an existing role (in which case, you should set member_role_id as well).The value passed as the keyword "rounds" to passlib's encrypt method. This option represents a trade off between security and performance. Higher values lead to slower performance, but higher security. Changing this option will only affect newly created passwords as existing password hashes already have a fixed number of rounds applied, so it is safe to tune this option in a running cluster. For more information, see https://pythonhosted.org/passlib/password_hash_api.html#choosing-the-right-rounds-valueThe maximum number of entities that will be returned in a collection. This global limit may be then overridden for a specific driver, by specifying a list_limit in the appropriate section (for example, `[assignment]`). No limit is set by default. In larger deployments, it is recommended that you set this to a reasonable number to prevent operations like listing all users and projects from placing an unnecessary load on the system.entities to be moved between domains by updating their `domain_id` attribute. commit_message:
fix cinder ceph backup driver padding error

While restore an extended source, ceph backup driver will pad
0 to the unused space if restore_discard_excess_bytes is True.
The original code use total length of the unused space to fill
each chunk. Change to use chunk size to fill each chunk.

Change-Id: I9658d31a55e5024f5f6d5ccf00939edd668ea451
Signed-off-by: Liu Qing <liuqing@chinac.com>
Closes-Bug: 1595014
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/29/332029/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: zeroes = '\0' * self.chunk_size

subject: Disable stonith temporarily during upgrades
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-29 13:17:45.000000000', 'files': ['extraconfig/tasks/major_upgrade_controller_pacemaker_1.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/d33f5905a652e6136e9048d135404eae3c7d0540', 'message': 'Disable stonith temporarily during upgrades

It is best if we disable stonith if a cluster has it configured and on,
before we call "pcs cluster stop --all", because should a service fail
to stop for whatever reason, pacemaker will fence the node where it
happened. This is something that we unlikely want during an upgrade as
it will make things worse.

Once the cluster is stopped we can reenable stonith (if it was enabled
to start with) in the CIB while the cluster is shut down.

Closes-Bug: #1596065

Change-Id: I38dcacfabc44539aab1f7da85168fe44a1b43a51
(cherry picked from commit 257855082abd78ac81407b8b11f8325fab649e8c)
'}]
commit_message:
Disable stonith temporarily during upgrades

It is best if we disable stonith if a cluster has it configured and on,
before we call "pcs cluster stop --all", because should a service fail
to stop for whatever reason, pacemaker will fence the node where it
happened. This is something that we unlikely want during an upgrade as
it will make things worse.

Once the cluster is stopped we can reenable stonith (if it was enabled
to start with) in the CIB while the cluster is shut down.

Closes-Bug: #1596065

Change-Id: I38dcacfabc44539aab1f7da85168fe44a1b43a51
(cherry picked from commit 257855082abd78ac81407b8b11f8325fab649e8c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/94/335494/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # We want to disable fencing during the cluster --stop as it might fence # nodes where a service fails to stop, which could be fatal during an upgrade # procedure. So we remember the stonith state. If it was enabled we reenable it # at the end of this script STONITH_STATE=$(pcs property show stonith-enabled | grep "stonith-enabled" | awk '{ print $2 }') pcs property set stonith-enabled=false # Let's reset the stonith back to true if it was true, before starting the cluster if [ $STONITH_STATE == "true" ]; then pcs -f /var/lib/pacemaker/cib/cib.xml property set stonith-enabled=true fi

deleted_lines: # Everything will be done in a tmp directoy. mkdir ~/tmp-build-for-arc-alc cd ~/tmp-build-for-arc-alc if hash scala 2>/dev/null; then # Scala is installed do nothing echo "Scala is already installed" else # Install it curl https://downloads.typesafe.com/scala/2.11.7/scala-2.11.7.deb > scala.deb sudo dpkg -i scala.deb # Install sbt echo "deb https://dl.bintray.com/sbt/debian /" | sudo tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list.d/sbt.list sudo -E apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 --recv 642AC823 sudo -E apt-get update sudo -E apt-get -y install sbt fi if [ "$SPARK_HOME" ]; then # Spark is installed and home is setup properly echo "Spark is already installed" else curl http://apache.arvixe.com/spark/spark-1.4.1/spark-1.4.1.tgz > spark.tgz tar -xzf spark.tgz mv spark-1.4.1/ ~/spark cd ~/spark mvn -DskipTests clean package cp ~/spark/conf/log4j.properties.template ~/spark/conf/log4j.properties sed -i 's/log4j.rootCategory=INFO/log4j.rootCategory=ERROR/g' ~/spark/conf/log4j.properties set -v echo 'export SPARK_HOME=~/spark' >> $HOME/.profile echo 'export PYTHONPATH=$SPARK_HOME/python:$SPARK_HOME/python/lib/py4j-0.8.2.1-src.zip:$PYTHONPATH' >> $HOME/.profile set +v cd ~/tmp-build-for-arc-alc fi if hash pep8 2>/dev/null; then echo "Pep8 is already installed!" else sudo -E apt-get -y install python-pip python-setuptools sudo -E pip install pep8 fi # Python dependencies sudo -E apt-get -y install python-numpy python-scipy ipython python-pyparsing sudo -E -H python setup.py develop # Remove tmp directory cd .. rm tmp-build-for-arc-alc

commit_message:
Fix multiple dimension query bug

Introduced by testing multiple dimensions not part of the same
dimension set.  Will revise help to text to indicate that isn't
supported -- we end up pruning more than expected. No bueno!

Change-Id: I58961861aa183eacab394aa803a6294fed493d70

commit_message:
Add docs for LBaaSv2 Horizon panels

This patch explains how to enable LBaaSv2 panels in Horizon using
the neutron-lbaas-dashboard plugin.

Closes-bug: 1595313

Change-Id: I82bc1240cd8c25359df13dcb6ce9f0770afb772a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/10/333010/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Add LBaaS panels in Horizon --------------------------- Horizon panels for managing LBaaSv2 are available starting with the Mitaka release. #. Clone the `neutron-lbaas-dashboard repository`_ and check out the release that corresponds to the version of Horizon that is installed: .. code-block:: console $ git clone http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-lbaas-dashboard/ $ cd neutron-lbaas-dashboard $ git checkout OPENSTACK_RELEASE #. Install the Horizon panel plugin: .. code-block:: console $ python setup.py install #. Copy the ``_1481_project_ng_loadbalancersv2_panel.py`` from the ``neutron-lbaas-dashboard/enabled`` directory into Horizon's ``openstack_dashboard/local/enabled`` directory. This step ensures that Horizon can find the plugin when it enumerates all of its available panels. #. Enable the plugin in Horizon by editing ``local_settings.py`` and setting ``enable_lb`` to ``True`` in the ``OPENSTACK_NEUTRON_NETWORK`` dictionary. #. If Horizon is configured to compress static files for better performance (usually set via ``COMPRESS_OFFLINE`` in the ``local_settings.py``), the static files must be optimized again: .. code-block:: console $ ./manage.py collectstatic $ ./manage.py compress #. Restart Apache to activate the new panel: .. code-block:: console $ sudo service apache2 restart To find the panel, click on **Project** in Horizon, then click the **Network** drop down, and click **Load Balancers**. .. _neutron-lbaas-dashboard repository: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron-lbaas-dashboard/

subject: Fix configuring mirror for CentOS in nodepool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-29 09:38:22.000000000', 'files': ['nodepool/scripts/configure_mirror.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/7c43abd15eaff86dc6af6b1204dee19b42635509', 'message': 'Fix configuring mirror for CentOS in nodepool

  * add NODEPOOL_CENTOS_MIRROR to set custom CentOS mirror in same manner
    as for Ubuntu
  * add NODEPOOL_EPEL_MIRROR to set custom EPEL mirror
  * use $releasever for CentOS and EPEL repositories

Change-Id: I93c92aea60725bb9b172e6fed12655e4a94b265b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix configuring mirror for CentOS in nodepool

  * add NODEPOOL_CENTOS_MIRROR to set custom CentOS mirror in same manner
    as for Ubuntu
  * add NODEPOOL_EPEL_MIRROR to set custom EPEL mirror
  * use $releasever for CentOS and EPEL repositories

Change-Id: I93c92aea60725bb9b172e6fed12655e4a94b265b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/99/335399/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NODEPOOL_CENTOS_MIRROR=${NODEPOOL_CENTOS_MIRROR:-http://$NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST/centos} NODEPOOL_EPEL_MIRROR=${NODEPOOL_EPEL_MIRROR:-http://$NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST/epel}baseurl=$NODEPOOL_CENTOS_MIRROR/\$releasever/os/\$basearch/gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-CentOS-\$releaseverbaseurl=$NODEPOOL_CENTOS_MIRROR/\$releasever/updates/\$basearch/gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-CentOS-\$releaseverbaseurl=$NODEPOOL_CENTOS_MIRROR/\$releasever/extras/\$basearch/gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-CentOS-\$releasevername=Extra Packages for Enterprise Linux \$releasever - \$basearch baseurl=$NODEPOOL_EPEL_MIRROR/\$releasever/\$basearchgpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-EPEL-\$releasever

subject: Detach volume after deleting instance with no host
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-10 19:03:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0d5d50c98e0d373a56be36283054fe8846bb4c62', 'message': 'Detach volume after deleting instance with no host

If an instance is booted from a volume, shelved, and goes into an error
state due to some reason. Volume from which instance is booted, remains
in-use state even the instance is deleted because instance has no host
associated with it.

Called _local_delete() to detach volume and destroy bdm if instance is
in shelved_offloaded state or has no host associated with it. This will
cleanup both volumes and the networks.

Note:
Ankit had submitted same patch [1] earlier which was reverted [2] due
to a race condition on jenkins if an instance is deleted when it is in
building state.  The patch was then rebumitted [3] fixing the
the failure of race condition by reverting the ObjectActionError
exception handling in _delete.  This patch was later re-reverted [4]
due to continued jenkins race conditions.

The current patch avoids the jenkins race condition by leaving the flow
for instances in the BUILDING state unchanged and only calling
_local_delete() on instances in the shelved_offloaded or error states
when the instance has no host associated with it.  This addresses the
concerns of the referenced bugs.

[1] Ic630ae7d026a9697afec46ac9ea40aea0f5b5ffb
[2] Id4e405e7579530ed1c1f22ccc972d45b6d185f41
[3] Ic107d8edc7ee7a4ebb04eac58ef0cdbf506d6173
[4] Ibcbe35b5d329b183c4d0e8233e8ada26ebc512c2

Co-Authored-By: Ankit Agrawal <ankit11.agrawal@nttdata.com>

Closes-Bug: 1404867
Closes-Bug: 1408527

Change-Id: I928a397c75b857e94bf5c002e50ec43a2bed9848

commit_message:
Detach volume after deleting instance with no host

If an instance is booted from a volume, shelved, and goes into an error
state due to some reason, the volume from which instance is booted
remains even the instance is deleted because instance has no host
associated with it.

Called _local_delete() to detach volume and destroy bdm if instance is
in shelved_offloaded state or has no host associated with it. This will
cleanup both volumes and the networks.

Note:
Ankit had submitted same patch [1] earlier which was reverted [2] due
to a race condition on jenkins if an instance is deleted when it is in
building state.  The patch was then rebumitted [3] fixing the
the failure of race condition by reverting the ObjectActionError
exception handling in _delete.  This patch was later re-reverted [4]
due to continued jenkins race conditions.

The current patch avoids the jenkins race condition by leaving the flow
for instances in the BUILDING state unchanged and only calling
_local_delete() on instances in the shelved_offloaded or error states
when the instance has no host associated with it.  This addresses the
concerns of the referenced bugs.

[1] Ic630ae7d026a9697afec46ac9ea40aea0f5b5ffb
[2] Id4e405e7579530ed1c1f22ccc972d45b6d185f41
[3] Ic107d8edc7ee7a4ebb04eac58ef0cdbf506d6173
[4] Ibcbe35b5d329b183c4d0e8233e8ada26ebc512c2

Co-Authored-By: Ankit Agrawal <ankit11.agrawal@nttdata.com>

Closes-Bug: 1404867
Closes-Bug: 1408527

Change-Id: I928a397c75b857e94bf5c002e50ec43a2bed9848

commit_message:
Print success/failure message after image build

It's often not clear whether an image build failed or succeeded
just from looking at the final output from dib.  This change prints
an explicit success message when the images build successfully, and
raises an exception if we attempt the build but the image files
don't exist after. The latter is being done because there seem to be
cases where dib will return 0 but for one reason or another the
image files aren't actually created.  The explicit file check
should ensure that if the client reports all images built, then at
least the expected files are there.

Change-Id: I5e7372d79f75037873ffd9c0664c53ad2b44396b

commit_message:
Fix search disk name for the config_drive in scenario test

This commit fixes search for config_drive device name in
test "verify_metadata_on_config_drive", that supports only lowercase.
It needs because "mkfs" tool, for example in RHEL, capitalize the label
for config_drive ("CONFIG-2" instead of "config-2"), that used
in test as filter for blkid.

Closes-Bug: #1596868
Change-Id: I09684a7a295ea12ac372aadac926fe34708a66d4

commit_message:
Add linux-image-extra-virtual to host packages

It appears that some Ubuntu 14.04 images only contain the base kernel package
and leave out the extra drivers package, linux-image-extra-$(uname -r).
If this package is not installed, openstack-ansible playbooks will fail on
modprobing kernel modules that are not installed (i.e. vhost_net.ko).
linux-image-extra-virtual should provide the linux-image-extra package for
currently installed base kernel package.

Change-Id: I7f788bfa1e2f42853075e27e8abdfa2a76336973
Closes-Bug: 1595323

commit_message:
Respect federated user name in tokens.

When user's name is specified in the mapping rules we should respect
this in mapped (federated) tokens.
This patch works fine for:

- Unscoped UUID tokens
- Scoped UUID tokens
- Unscoped Fernet tokens

It will not work for scoped Fernet tokens as information about user's
name is not persisted in the encrypted/compressed payload.

Change-Id: I0009e04506308a3128a51d892fc7618bb3d9b3fe
Partial-Bug: #1482701

commit_message:
Replace tempest_lib with tempest.lib

As the tempest_lib is deprecated and the code has been moved into
tempest. We should use tempest.lib insteded of tempest_lib.

commit_message:
Allow middleware to override metadata header checking

Middleware (e.g. an encrypter) may need to modify user metadata header
values such that they violate the constraints (e.g. an encrypted value
may be longer than the plaintext value). This should be ok provided
the middleware first applies the constraints checks.

This patch modifies check_metadata to store the checked state in a
request header 'X-Backend-Metadata-Checked' and not repeat the checks
if they have already been successful.

Co-Authored-By: Janie Richling <jrichli@us.ibm.com>

Change-Id: I7732f13b06c8826537b8f8230a2785607790b8e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/07/328207/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from swift.common.utils import list_from_csv Parse SWIFT_CONF_FILE and reset module level global constraint attrs, If successful, the check will only be made on the first call to this method for a particular request and target type. Subsequent calls for the same request and target type will skip the checks, unless the target type has been removed from the comma-separated list stored under the key 'X-Backend-Metadata-Checked' in the request. This allows middleware to apply the checks and then modify the metadata headers, possibly violating the constraints. checked = list_from_csv(req.headers.get('X-Backend-Metadata-Checked')) if target_type in checked: return checked.append(target_type) req.headers['X-Backend-Metadata-Checked'] = ','.join(checked)
deleted_lines: Parse SWIFT_CONF_FILE and reset module level global contraint attrs,

commit_message:
Add policy sample generation

This adds the entry point and config file necessary for using the
oslo.policy sample generation script. It also adds a tox target to
simplify the usage of it.

The command is also run in the docs tox target since the sample file
can be considered documentation.

Change-Id: I18a1fa567fc04b0e0a37c02f20024b2ce483f060
Partially-Implements: bp policy-in-code

'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2016-01-22 23:41:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/817757b38c7cfb5fd31d3a8ad92cb64a9bdab0f9', 'message': 'Magnum asynchronous container operation

For design details, please refer to the Whiteboard at
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/async-container-operations

To try out this feature, apply the patch on your devstack, enable the
config, as shown in etc/magnum/magnum.conf.sample, and restart
magnum-api and magnum-conductor.

Change-Id: I19bdb4006ca6c004876c4e04c664379be06a146c
Implements: blueprint async-container-operations
Implements: blueprint async-rpc-api
'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2016-01-26 20:46:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/magnum/commit/9f495336e0ee486ca00bcb2dc06943ba5cb6cd07', 'message': "Magnum asynchronous container operation

Here is a summary of the design -
- For ease of adoption, the async_mode of communication between
  API-conductor, conductor-COE in magnum, can be controlled using a
  configuration option. So the code-path for sync mode and async mode
  would co-exist for now. To achieve this with minimal/no code
  duplication and cleaner interface, we are using openstack/futurist.
- There are two classes of container operations - one that can be made
  async, viz. create/delete/start/stop/pause/unpause/reboot, which do
  not need data about the container in return. The other type requires
  data, viz. container-logs. For async-type container-operations,
  magnum-API uses CAST instead of CALL from oslo_messaging.
- magnum conductor maintains a queue of async container-operations, per
  bay per container, which is executed in sequence, preserving
  chronological ordering by a greenthread from the pool.
- 'create-in-progress', 'delete-in-progress' - status is reflected on
  the container object.
- If an operation in progress, in async-mode, do not allow 'container
  show' to over-write the state of the container.
- Communication with COE has to be more resilient, when multiple
  operations are in progress.

To try out this feature, apply the patch on your devstack, enable the
config, as shown in etc/magnum/magnum.conf.sample, and restart
magnum-api and magnum-conductor.

A snippet showing the timing improvement from async mode on devstack
https://gist.github.com/surojit-pathak/2cbdad5b8bf5b569e755

Change-Id: I19bdb4006ca6c004876c4e04c664379be06a146c
Implements: blueprint async-container-operations
Implements: blueprint async-rpc-api

commit_message:
Magnum asynchronous container operation

The spec for this design is
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/275003/

To try out this feature, apply the patch on your devstack, enable the
config, as shown in etc/magnum/magnum.conf.sample, and restart
magnum-api and magnum-conductor.

A snippet showing the timing improvement from async mode on devstack
https://gist.github.com/surojit-pathak/2cbdad5b8bf5b569e755

Change-Id: I19bdb4006ca6c004876c4e04c664379be06a146c
Implements: blueprint async-container-operations
Implements: blueprint async-rpc-api

commit_message:
make dependency validator dynamically registerable

Since many resources will be added in future. e.g. l2gw, qos in near
future, it's quite troublesome to maintain
dependecy_validation.VALIDATION_MAP cleanly.
This patch introduces interface for registration of validation function
to allow each code introducing new resource to their own validation
function easily without touching journal/dependency_validations.py

Change-Id: I2a385753583677cf68e0d075df2f71f2b6a6146f

commit_message:
Add Spec for QoS driver

This is a spec for qos driver in networking-odl which is intended
for the intergration of neutron qos api in openstack with ODL

Partially Implements: blueprint qos-driver

Change-Id: Ib52fb8ba696d56c9292942139ff6e0663758bac0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/21/314221/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================================== Quality of Service Driver for OpenDaylight ========================================== This spec describes the plan to implement quality of service driver for OpenDaylight Controller. Problem Statement =================== OpenStack networking project (neutron [1]) have a extension plugin implemented and which expose api for quality of service that can be also be implemented by any backend networking service provider to support qos. These APIs provide a way to integrate OpenStack Neutron QOS with any of the backend QOS providers. OpenDay light provides a QOS service for bandwidth and dscp marking but a driver is needed to integrate that api provided by openstack neutron with service in ODL Proposed Change =============== Implementation of this spec will introduce a neutron QOS driver for OpenDaylight Controller in networking-odl project that will pass through the neutron QOS API's call to the OpenDaylight Controller. Detailed Design =============== To enable the formal end to end integration between OpenStack QOS and OpenDaylight requires an QOS driver for OpenDaylight. ODL QOS driver will act as a shim layer between OpenStack and OpenDaylight that will carry out following two main tasks: * Translation of OpenStack neutron QOS API to ODL QOS classifier yang models** * Translation of OpenStack neutron QOS API's to OpenDaylight Neutron Northbound QOS models** ** This work is not yet completely done, The OpenDaylight neutron northbound project yang model is under review for QOS. These models will be based on the existing neutron qos plugin APIs. This work is out of scope of networking-odl work and will be collaborated in the scope of the OpenDaylight Neutron Northbound project. QOS providers in OpenDaylight can listen to these OpenDaylight Neutron Northbound QOS models and translate it to their specific yang models for classification/qos. The following diagram shows the high level integration between OpenStack and the OpenDaylight QOS provider:: +---------------------------------------------+ | OpenStack Network Server (neutron qos) | | +-------------------+ | | | networking-odl | | | | QOS Driver | | | +-------------------+ | +----------------------|----------------------+ | REST Communication | ----------------------- OpenDaylight Controller | | +-----------------------|-----------------------|---------------+ | +----------v----+ +---v---+ | | Neutron | QOS Classifier| |QOS | Neutron | | Northbound | Models | |Models | Northbound| | Project +---------------+ +-------+ Project | | / \ | | | / \ | | | / \ | | | +-----V---+ +----V----+ +---V---+ | | | QOS | | QOS | | provider| ... | provider| | QOS | ... | +---------+ +---------+ +-------+ | +-----------|----------------|------------------|---------------+ | | | | | | +-----------V----------------V------------------V---------------+ | Network/OVS | | | +---------------------------------------------------------------+ In the above architecture, the opendaylight components are shown just to understand the overall architecture, but it's out of scope of this spec's work items. This spec will only track progress related to networking-odl OpenStack QOS driver work. Dependencies ============ It has a dependency on OpenDaylight Neutron Northbound QOS classifier and chain yang models, but that is out of scope of this spec. Impact ====== None Assignee(s) =========== Following developers will be the initial contributor to the driver, but we will be happy to have more contributor on board. * Manjeet Singh Bhatia (manjeet.s.bhatia@intel.com, irc: manjeets) References ========== [1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/neutron/devref/quality_of_service.html [2] https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/NeutronNorthbound:Main

Allow configuration of bridges through devstack by configuring
ODL_CONFIG_BRIDGES=True

This complements loading ODL in an 'externalodl' mode, with the feature
odl-netvirt-vpnservice-openstack installed.

Alternatively, this allows installing ODL in odl-server mode,
by configuring the following in addition to ODL_CONFIG_BRIDGES

commit_message:
devstack: support bridge configuration, for vpnservice-openstack

Allow configuration of bridges through devstack by configuring
ODL_CONFIG_BRIDGES=True

This complements loading ODL in an 'externalodl' mode, with the
feature odl-netvirt-vpnservice-openstack installed.

Alternatively, this allows installing ODL in odl-server mode,
by configuring ODL_NETVIRT_KARAF_FEATURE and ODL_BOOT_WAIT_URL,
in addition to ODL_CONFIG_BRIDGES -- please see README.rst

Related-Bug: #1588008
Change-Id: I19b5472b3129f1bf209cfc0a3a65a58a0ca51974
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/81/331481/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if ! [ "$ODL_CONFIG_BRIDGES" ]; then if [[ "$ODL_NETVIRT_KARAF_FEATURE" =~ odl-netvirt-vpnservice-openstack ]]; then ODL_CONFIG_BRIDGES="True" else ODL_CONFIG_BRIDGES="False" fi fi if [ "$ODL_CONFIG_BRIDGES" == "True" ]; then echo_summary "Configuring bridges manually (vpnservice workaround)" bind_opendaylight_controller_configure_bridges fi } function bind_opendaylight_controller_configure_bridges { sudo ovs-vsctl --may-exist add-br br-ex sudo ovs-vsctl --may-exist add-br br-int sudo ovs-vsctl set bridge br-int protocols=OpenFlow13 ODL_CTL_PORT=${ODL_CTL_PORT:-6653} local ODL_OVS_CONTROLLERS=${ODL_OVS_MANAGERS:-$ODL_MGR_IP} local ODL_CONTROLLERS_PARAM=() for controller in $(echo $ODL_OVS_CONTROLLERS | tr "," "\n"); do ODL_CONTROLLERS_PARAM=( "${ODL_CONTROLLERS_PARAM[@]}" "tcp:$controller:$ODL_CTL_PORT" ) done sudo ovs-vsctl set-controller br-int ${ODL_CONTROLLERS_PARAM[@]} sudo ovs-vsctl set-controller br-ex ${ODL_CONTROLLERS_PARAM[@]} }

commit_message:
create dir, doc/specs, for spec

From newton cycle, networking-odl project will adopt spec process
in light weight manner to track its tasks and tech details.
This isn't intended to replace Neutron Stadium Evolution[1], but
to complement it to address networking-odl project specific stuff.
Specs are not for users/operators, but for developers. So it's
better to store those files for specs separated. If it's user facing
feature or public API, it should go to neutron spec process.

The full fledged process similar to core neutron wouldn't be
worthwhile because networking-odl is much smaller. And specs for
networking-odl will be stored in networking-odl repo for now as small
start. This might be revised later.
This patch creates doc/specs directory and moves related specs files
under it.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/312199/ Neutron Stadium Evolution
Change-Id: Ide74a98251078a22d59032010a4e2c06be6afc77
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/52/324052/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add NBD driver

Change-Id: I21b2029c172aabf90d7c69e83225b0954820352d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/23/335523/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =============================== NexentaEdge NBD & iSCSI drivers ===============================servers, and builds on Nexenta IP and patent pending Cloud Copy On Write (CCOW) technology to break new ground in terms of reliability, functionality and cost efficiency. # IP address of the gateway node attached to iSCSI service above or # virtual IP address if an iSCSI Storage Service Group is configured in # HA mode (string value)Supported operations -------------------- * Create, delete, attach, and detach volumes. * Create, list, and delete volume snapshots. * Create a volume from a snapshot. * Copy an image to a volume. * Copy a volume to an image. * Clone a volume. * Extend a volume. NBD driver ~~~~~~~~~~ As an alternative to using iSCSI, Amazon S3, or Openstack Swift protocols, NexentaEdge can provide access to cluster storage via a Network Block Device (NBD) interface. The NexentaEdge cluster must be installed and configured according to the relevant Nexenta documentation. A cluster, tenant, bucket must be pre-created. The driver requires NexentaEdge Service to run on Hypervisor Node (Nova) node. The node must sit on Replicast Network and only runs NexentaEdge service, does not require physical disks. You must configure these items for each NexentaEdge cluster that the NBD volume driver controls: #. Make the following changes on data node ``/etc/cinder/cinder.conf`` file. .. code-block:: ini # Enable Nexenta NBD driver volume_driver = cinder.volume.drivers.nexenta.nexentaedge.nbd.NexentaEdgeNBDDriver # Specify the ip address for Rest API (string value) nexenta_rest_address = MANAGEMENT-NODE-IP # Port for Rest API (integer value) nexenta_rest_port = 8080 # Protocol used for Rest calls (string value, default=htpp) nexenta_rest_protocol = http # Username for NexentaEdge Rest (string value) nexenta_rest_user = USERNAME # Password for NexentaEdge Rest (string value) nexenta_rest_password = PASSWORD # Path to bucket containing iSCSI LUNs (string value) nexenta_lun_container = CLUSTER/TENANT/BUCKET # Path to directory to store symbolic links to block devices # (string value, default=/dev/disk/by-path) nexenta_nbd_symlinks_dir = /PATH/TO/SYMBOLIC/LINKS #. Save the changes to the ``/etc/cinder/cinder.conf`` file and restart the ``cinder-volume`` service. Supported operations -------------------- * Create, delete, attach, and detach volumes. * Create, list, and delete volume snapshots. * Create a volume from a snapshot. * Copy an image to a volume. * Copy a volume to an image. * Clone a volume. * Extend a volume.
deleted_lines: ======================== NexentaEdge iSCSI driver ========================servers, and builds on Nexenta IP and patent pending Cloud Copy On Write(CCOW) technology to break new grounds in terms of reliability, functionality and cost efficiencies.Supported operations ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * Create, delete, attach, and detach volumes. * Create, list, and delete volume snapshots. * Create a volume from a snapshot. * Copy an image to a volume. * Copy a volume to an image. * Clone a volume. * Extend a volume. # IP address of the gateway node attached to iSCSI service above (string value)

commit_message:
Added the ip_vs kernel module to all openstack hosts

The "ip_vs" module is needed in high availability situations where
keepalived is used, specifically Neutron L3HA. Without this module
loaded the neutron l3 agent can crash like so:

    neutron_agents_container-cf16a000/modprobe.log:1:Jun 27 15:09:02
      neutron_agents_container-cf16a000 modprobe: ERROR: could not
      insert 'ip_vs': Operation not permitted ?

Backport-Of: I957462f0adafcbe9655696d8f9aed7252f5c85c3

Change-Id: I21e2ffd050074f578521b41232dfec88aadca9b0
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts refs/changes/01/334701/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - ip_vs

'}, {'number': 25, 'created': '2015-08-12 10:17:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/db421a2086a7b7827c2bc3e9cc0209f793bfc6f6', 'message': 'libvirt: virtuozzo instance resize support

Adapt "nova resize" code to support Virtuozzo ploop disks.
As far as ploop disks are in fact directories we add '-r' argument
to all utilities that deal with instance' disks such as cp, rsync and scp.
Thus we copy disks universally whether they are folders or files.

Also using "prl_disk_tool" instead of "qemu-img" is better for ploop images
because it resizes guest filesystem as well.

Co-Authored-By: Maxim Nestratov <mnestratov@virtuozzo.com>

Change-Id: I38dbf73beb01fe1939ddca63fbfedbec1dc3c826
Implements: blueprint virtuozzo-instance-resize-support

'}, {'number': 28, 'created': '2015-10-09 14:37:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1bcef0f0d0b3eab83908b7a9a7d53e5bc7adc921', 'message': 'libvirt: virtuozzo instance resize support

Adapt "nova resize" code to support Virtuozzo ploop disks.
As far as ploop disks are in fact directories we add '-r' argument
to all utilities that deal with instance' disks such as cp, rsync and scp.
Thus we copy disks universally whether they are folders or files.

Also using "prl_disk_tool" instead of "qemu-img" is better for ploop images
because it resizes guest filesystem as well.

We can't resize disks from guest OS in containers,
because they are not allowed to write directly to block device.
ploop tool can resize partition table and internal filesystem,
but only for container's disks. Such disks must have only one partition
with ext filesystem.

prl_disk_tool can resize disks with internal filesystems
and doesn't require any special layout so it can resize disks
for virtual machines.  So it's better to use this tool instead of ploop.

Co-Authored-By: Maxim Nestratov <mnestratov@virtuozzo.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Guryanov <dguryanov@parallels.com>

Change-Id: I38dbf73beb01fe1939ddca63fbfedbec1dc3c826
Implements: blueprint virtuozzo-instance-resize-support

'}, {'number': 40, 'created': '2016-06-18 13:16:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/891213e63cd71888e77b8431327a0f3bc909d754', 'message': 'libvirt: virtuozzo instance resize support

Adapt "nova resize" code to support Virtuozzo ploop disks.
As far as ploop disks are in fact directories we add '-r' argument
to all utilities that deal with instance' disks such as cp, rsync and scp.
Thus we copy disks universally whether they are folders or files.

Also using "prl_disk_tool" instead of "qemu-img" is better for ploop images
because it resizes guest filesystem as well.

We can't resize disks from guest OS in containers,
because they are not allowed to write directly to block device.
ploop tool can resize partition table and internal filesystem,
but only for container's disks. Such disks must have only one partition
with ext filesystem.

prl_disk_tool can resize disks with internal filesystems
and doesn't require any special layout so it can resize disks
for virtual machines.  So it's better to use this tool instead of ploop.

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Guryanov <dguryanov@parallels.com>

Depends-on: I7bac5511df1f30ded3cea263e6b46e605e20e5fb
Change-Id: I38dbf73beb01fe1939ddca63fbfedbec1dc3c826
Implements: blueprint virtuozzo-instance-resize-support

'}, {'number': 58, 'created': '2016-06-27 18:17:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/016a782a60dc6b48f2e06278f2177ffe74feb5f8', 'message': 'libvirt: virtuozzo instance resize support

Adapt "nova resize" code to support Virtuozzo ploop disks.
As far as ploop disks are in fact directories we add '-r' argument
to all utilities that deal with instance' disks such as cp, rsync and scp.
Thus we copy disks universally whether they are folders or files.

Also using "prl_disk_tool" instead of "qemu-img" is better for ploop images
because it resizes guest filesystem as well.

We can't resize disks from guest OS in containers,
because they are not allowed to write directly to block device.
ploop tool can resize partition table and internal filesystem,
but only for container's disks. Such disks must have only one partition
with ext filesystem.

prl_disk_tool can resize disks with internal filesystems
and doesn't require any special layout so it can resize disks
for virtual machines.  So it's better to use this tool instead of ploop.

Also we make compute.filters more strict
We call "ploop" only with "grow" argument
And we set disk size in megabytes for prl_disk_tool

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Guryanov <dguryanov@parallels.com>
Depends-On: I04c4379459c2fc1fd4801ec2aad53d0f6053b6d6
Change-Id: I38dbf73beb01fe1939ddca63fbfedbec1dc3c826
Implements: blueprint virtuozzo-instance-resize-support

We call "ploop" only with "restore-descriptor" argument
And we set disk size in megabytes for prl_disk_tool

commit_message:
libvirt: virtuozzo instance resize support

Adapt "nova resize" code to support Virtuozzo ploop disks.
As far as ploop disks are in fact directories we add '-r' argument
to all utilities that deal with instance' disks such as cp, rsync and scp.
Thus we copy disks universally whether they are folders or files.

Also using "prl_disk_tool" instead of "qemu-img" is better for ploop images
because it resizes guest filesystem as well.

We can't resize disks from guest OS in containers,
because they are not allowed to write directly to block device.
ploop tool can resize partition table and internal filesystem,
but only for container's disks. Such disks must have only one partition
with ext filesystem.

prl_disk_tool can resize disks with internal filesystems
and doesn't require any special layout so it can resize disks
for virtual machines.  So it's better to use this tool instead of ploop.

Also we make compute.filters more strict
We call "ploop" only with "restore-descriptor" argument
And we set disk size in megabytes for prl_disk_tool

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Guryanov <dguryanov@parallels.com>
Depends-On: I04c4379459c2fc1fd4801ec2aad53d0f6053b6d6
Change-Id: I38dbf73beb01fe1939ddca63fbfedbec1dc3c826
Implements: blueprint virtuozzo-instance-resize-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/57/182257/54 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def extend(image, size, use_cow=False, is_ploop=False): if is_ploop: gbytes_size = str(size / 1073741824) + 'G'; utils.execute('prl_disk_tool', 'resize', '--size', gbytes_size, '--resize_partition', '--hdd', image, run_as_root=True) return

commit_message:
migration: split libvirt & nova configs

When running micro-services on compute nodes, nova & libvirt are
separated & isolated (ie: containers).
nova::migration::libvirt used to configure both nova & libvirt to
support migration.

This patch makes possible to select what we want (libvirt, nova or
both). It will configure all by default for backward compatibility.

Depends-On: I33e565638f39ace819645215912303d6e431870c
Change-Id: I1a1cb827512b12289558b296a7e64ce2dc71f00a

commit_message:
Make clean_iptables really clean all entries

The old code creates a list of commands and pipes it into bash. Under
certain circumstances, i.e. running under Ubuntu Vivid, the first
command eats up all of stdin, resulting in the following commands not
being executed.

Fix that by writing all of the commands into a tmpfile first, which is
then executed by bash.

Change-Id: If3edbf21e0e87cbba4f893385ed53f25faf1f551
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/01/182301/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tmpfile=$(mktemp) sudo iptables -S -v | sed "s/-c [0-9]* [0-9]* //g" | grep "nova" | grep "\-A" | sed "s/-A/-D/g" | awk '{print "sudo iptables",$0}' > $tmpfile sudo iptables -S -v -t nat | sed "s/-c [0-9]* [0-9]* //g" | grep "nova" | grep "\-A" | sed "s/-A/-D/g" | awk '{print "sudo iptables -t nat",$0}' >> $tmpfile sudo iptables -S -v | sed "s/-c [0-9]* [0-9]* //g" | grep "nova" | grep "\-N" | sed "s/-N/-X/g" | awk '{print "sudo iptables",$0}' >> $tmpfile sudo iptables -S -v -t nat | sed "s/-c [0-9]* [0-9]* //g" | grep "nova" | grep "\-N" | sed "s/-N/-X/g" | awk '{print "sudo iptables -t nat",$0}' >> $tmpfile bash $tmpfile rm -f $tmpfile
deleted_lines: sudo iptables -S -v | sed "s/-c [0-9]* [0-9]* //g" | grep "nova" | grep "\-A" | sed "s/-A/-D/g" | awk '{print "sudo iptables",$0}' | bash sudo iptables -S -v -t nat | sed "s/-c [0-9]* [0-9]* //g" | grep "nova" | grep "\-A" | sed "s/-A/-D/g" | awk '{print "sudo iptables -t nat",$0}' | bash sudo iptables -S -v | sed "s/-c [0-9]* [0-9]* //g" | grep "nova" | grep "\-N" | sed "s/-N/-X/g" | awk '{print "sudo iptables",$0}' | bash sudo iptables -S -v -t nat | sed "s/-c [0-9]* [0-9]* //g" | grep "nova" | grep "\-N" | sed "s/-N/-X/g" | awk '{print "sudo iptables -t nat",$0}' | bash

commit_message:
Make trove tempest job nv until plugin is added

Tempest recently removed it's tests for trove in preparation for the
trove plugin being completed. This commit makes the tempest trove job
non voting until it's migrated to using the plugin so as to not block
trove development in the meantime.

Change-Id: I8f896fb77dc1e3bd58e8b7905958c6e505d22627

commit_message:
Copy measurement before destructive update

When forwarding from the agent to the Monasca API a destructive update was
performed on the measurement data.  If the forwarding failed the data would be
processed a second time but since it was already modified the second processing
would fail.

Change-Id: Ia58ff12f3f13911fdbc6588be20820335f3f6589
Closes-Bug: #1596684
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/60/335160/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: measurement = copy.deepcopy(measurement)

commit_message:
Fix ceilometer auth url

Due to a recent change introduced in puppet ceilometer[1]
ceilometer auth type defaults to password type and v2
auth_url doesnt work with domain. This fixes the url to
not include suffix.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/320454/

Change-Id: Ibce716825c95e36a942203be2c67ea0da79503f2

utility to list any missing system requirements.

This change is needed since the infra team will not install standard
packages in jobs anymore, projects should use other-requirements.txt
instead. The macros xvfb-install, firefox-install, chrome-install
which are used to run some jobs for this repository will be removed
soon.

This change is self-testing.

For other-requirements.txt see also
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#package-requirements

[*] http://docs.openstack.org/infra/bindep/

Change-Id: I3c62f6924d2d70e23e6787b8da848fbeb0d52ddc

commit_message:
List system dependencies for running common tests

Add an other-requirements.txt file containing a cross-platform list
of dependencies needed for running included tox-based tests. Also
include a tox environment for convenience calling the bindep[*]
utility to list any missing system requirements.

This change is self-testing.

For other-requirements.txt see also
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#package-requirements

[*] http://docs.openstack.org/infra/bindep/

Change-Id: I3c62f6924d2d70e23e6787b8da848fbeb0d52ddc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/84/334984/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:bindep] # Do not install any requirements. We want this to be fast and work even if # system dependencies are missing, since it's used to tell you what system # dependencies are missing! This also means that bindep must be installed # separately, outside of the requirements files. deps = bindep commands = bindep test

commit_message:
Updated the hostname generation

The change simply adds a more complete hostname within the
"/etc/hosts" file for all nodes within inventory which
ensures all hosts are reachable and have a proper host entry
for itself and all other hosts. Additionally the hostname
insert script has been made idempotent and tests have been
added to ensure functionality.

Partial-Bug: #1577245
Change-Id: Ib1e3b6f02758906e3ec7ab35737c1a58fcbca216
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Fixed type:dict validator passes unexpected keys

Validation should fail if passed parameter
does not match defined schema.

Change-Id: Ia93ff849396c6e2a5a170d7c01629a38e412f037
Closes-Bug: #1573605
Signed-off-by: Pavel Gluschak <trustytwelve@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/64/309964/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_validate_dict_unexpected_keys(self): dictionary, constraints = self._construct_dict_and_constraints() dictionary['unexpected_key'] = 'val' msg = validators.validate_dict(dictionary, constraints) self.assertIn('Unexpected keys supplied:', msg)

commit_message:
fix job-stop request not accepted

A job whose status is "stop" and event is "start" can now be correctly
stopped. Its status will remain "stop" and its event set to "stop"

Client are actually free to issue any start/stop request,
the responsibility of detecting if the action request
makes sense is on the scheduler

Change-Id: I82da538840d67cbaed06a54a6c71e2bf75a174de
Closes-Bug: #1570401
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer-api refs/changes/58/305958/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.job_schedule.get('event') != 'start': return 'start already requested' if self.job_schedule.get('event') != 'stop': return 'stop already requested' if self.job_schedule.get('event') != 'abort': return 'abort already requested'
deleted_lines: if self.job_status in ["scheduled", "running"]: return 'already active' if self.job_status in ["completed", "stop", ""]: # completed jobs are not acquired by the scheduler self.job_status = 'stop' self.job_schedule['result'] = '' else: raise freezer_api_exc.BadDataFormat("unable to start a {0} job" .format(self.job_status)) if self.job_status in ["scheduled", "running", ""]: else: return 'already stopped' if self.job_status in ["scheduled", "running", ""]: else: return 'already stopped'

commit_message:
Add a global fix for anything that involves GetHashPrefixAndSuffix

We tackled this previously with commit
6f78542637b80671cf3153dad8e15ce54dedbb39, but that fix did not
go far enough. Other modules invoke ./hummingbird, so their tests
need the same faking that makeReplicator() needs.

Note that we have 2 kinds of tests: the one that tests the
GetHashPrefixAndSuffix itself and the rest, which uses the
GetHashPrefixAndSuffix in the process of testing something else.
We create a test file for the former and fake everything without
any files for the latter.

Change-Id: Id87cfa6f5271111ae194316de170c6707ba6f23c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/08/333108/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: swift_conf_name, err := FakeHashPrefixAndSuffix() defer os.Remove(swift_conf_name)
deleted_lines: var config_source []byte = []byte( "[swift-hash]\n" + "swift_hash_path_suffix = 983abc1de3ff4258\n") tempFile, _ := ioutil.TempFile("", "swift.conf-") defer os.RemoveAll(tempFile.Name()) ioutil.WriteFile(tempFile.Name(), config_source, 0600) configLocations = []string{tempFile.Name()}

commit_message:
On port update check port binding worked

When updating a port, we should do the same port binding check that we
do when creating a port.

Although in the case of update, we can use the existing clean up code
that ensures we only delete the port if it was created by Nova.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling

Change-Id: I3ac06f45305aea5e0c18ba777331fb2f233523f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/327012/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _ensure_port_binding_success(self, port_client, port_response, delete_on_error): if delete_on_error: port_id = port_response['port']['id'] port_client.delete_port(port_id) self._ensure_port_binding_success( port_client, port_response, delete_on_error=True) port_response = port_client.update_port( port['id'], port_req_body) self._ensure_port_binding_success( port_client, port_response, delete_on_error=False)
deleted_lines: def _ensure_port_binding_success(self, port_client, port_response): port_id = port_response['port']['id'] port_client.delete_port(port_id) self._ensure_port_binding_success(port_client, port_response) port_client.update_port(port['id'], port_req_body)

commit_message:
Refactor to create _ensure_no_port_binding_failure

Extract the logic that checks the port binding, so it can be used in two
places, in a later patch.

blueprint prep-for-network-aware-scheduling

Change-Id: I21f16a7f5508618d0b5a4427c041007cd9760c02
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/11/327011/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _ensure_port_binding_success(self, port_client, port_response): if (port_response['port'].get('binding:vif_type') == network_model.VIF_TYPE_BINDING_FAILED): port_id = port_response['port']['id'] port_client.delete_port(port_id) raise exception.PortBindingFailed(port_id=port_id) port_response = port_client.create_port(port_req_body) self._ensure_port_binding_success(port_client, port_response) port_id = port_response['port']['id']
deleted_lines: port = port_client.create_port(port_req_body) port_id = port['port']['id'] if (port['port'].get('binding:vif_type') == network_model.VIF_TYPE_BINDING_FAILED): port_client.delete_port(port_id) raise exception.PortBindingFailed(port_id=port_id)

commit_message:
Change to Linux kernel bonding in the sample NIC templates.

This change modifies the sample templates in
network/config/bond-with-vlans to use Linux kernel bonding rather
than OVS bonds. The reason for this change is that Linux kernel
bonding is the preferred method when using LACP bonds. OVS (at
least version 2.4) has been shown to experience packet loss under
load when using LACP protocol. Linux kernel bonding does not have
this issue.

There is a Red Hat bug on the OVS Bond w/LACP packet loss issue:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1289825

Change-Id: I66aaf34c25c632525c12c694598640a6a0881b69
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/09/283209/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: type: linux_bond bonding_options: {get_param: BondInterfaceOvsOptions}

commit_message:
request_without_retry was retrying once.

This was an off by one error.  The test with current is strictly

commit_message:
Allow to specify templates path on overcloud deployment

It can be useful when we have to deploy against a different
set of templates. The template path can just be passed with the
extra-vars option in bash script.

Change-Id: I68991f977ef868b78aa11907fba80634a7d0e923

is fixed and the job is stable, it will be switched to voting.

commit_message:
Remove senlin-dsvm-functional gate job

This patch removes senlin-dsvm-functional gate job which has
been replaced by senlin-dsvm-tempest-functional. It also adds
senlin-dsvm-tempest-functional job to both check and gate
pipelines and makes it vote.

Change-Id: I7e7de9f8f4e44d485160820f8788f657f26c1d3b

commit_message:
Naming convention
Implements: blueprint Naming Convention for Records

Change-Id: I1c0bdd0d3fbdb0dddf88bab7213ad32bd91886a1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate-specs refs/changes/36/322936/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= The title of your blueprint ============================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/designate/+spec/different-format-for-ipv4-and-ipv6 Naming Conventions for records Right now we have a single format to define FQDN for records created through designate sink. Problem description =================== At present there is only one format we can define for both IPv4 and IPv6 ips. If a user want to have different naming convention for records created through Sink service we dont have a way to do that since there is only one option in designate.conf where we defing the FQDN format. Proposed change =============== In designate.conf we should give an option under the Sink configuration where we can define two different formats for IPv4 and IPv6. Similarly in we need to make appropriate changes in sink code under designate/notification_handler/ for base.py, nova.py and neutron.py SINK Changes ------------ Base.py, nova.py and neutron.py needs to be changed to get the format type from designate.conf. The new formats that we need to get are formatv4 and formatv6 which will now be implemented in designate.conf. API Changes ----------- None Central Changes --------------- None Storage Changes --------------- None Other Changes ------------- None Alternatives ------------ This is an optional section, where it does apply we'd just like a demonstration that some thought has been put into why the proposed approach is the best one. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Kumar Acharya<ma501v> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Mitaka-3 Work Items ---------- Define the format for IPV4 and IPv6 FQDN and Implement it in designate.conf Code changes required in designate Dependencies ============ formatv4 and formatv6 should be implemented in designate.conf as new format types

commit_message:
Catch duplicate db inserts in powerdns plugin

Catches duplicate db exceptions in the powerdns plugin, allowing it
to recover when a create is initially successful, but doesn't propagate
fast enough

Change-Id: I1a9d66c069b1f0f231618a369e31ce9be2e3c5c5
closes-bug: 1594582

the utils.create_cephx_key() function.

commit_message:
Script Installer for fuel-devops.

- Script will help to install different versions of fuel-devops.

Change-Id: I69816cca9148e6f0c077f5191b4e227a28fa56a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-devops refs/changes/34/332734/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. set -ex package_list="git,libyaml-dev,libffi-dev,python-dev,python-pip,qemu,libvirt-bin,libvirt-dev,vlan,bridge-utils,genisoimage" longopts="interactive,help,no-venv,clean-install,pgsql-auth-trust,force-yes,pgsql,pg-user:,pg-password:,pg-database:,sqlite-database:,install-repo-requirements:,venv-name:,devops-tag:" venv_packs="python-virtualenv,libpq-dev,libgmp-dev,pkg-config" #Description of all possible options usage() { cat << EOF Usage $0 [OPTIONS]...VALUE ######################################################################################################################################################################## # -I (--interactive) - Option makes script to ask questions. # # -H/-h (--help) - Show this help. # # -E (--no-venv) - Install devops into the system (without venv) OPTIONAL. # # -C (--clean-install) - Remove all previous installed devops packages/databases. # # -A (--pgsql-auth-trust) - Change auth method to trust insteacd of peer (required --pgsql). # # -P (--pgsql) - Use pgsql db instead of sqlite3. # # -U (--pg-user) - User for devops database (required --pgsql) DEFAULT value "fuel_devops". # # -p (--pg_password) - User password for potgreSQL (required --pgsql) DEFAULT value "fuel_devops" . # # -D (--pg_database) - Name of PostgreSQL database (required --pgsql) DEFAULT value "fuel_devops". # # -S (--sqlite_database) - Path to the sqlite database with the name (e.g. /path/somewhere/database_name) DEFAULT $HOME/devops_${DEVOPS_TAG}.sqlite3. # # -R (--install-repo-requirements) - URL to the file with requirements for additional packages (for now fuel-qa only) NOT working for now. # # -N (--venv-name) - Name with path to python venv (example: ~/devops_venv) required. # # -T (--devops-tag) - Tag that will be used as source of devopsa package DEFAULT is master branch without tag. # # -F (--force-yes) - Yes to all additional changes (required SUDO PASSWD or run by root). # ######################################################################################################################################################################## EOF } #Options parser function. opts() { opt=$(getopt -o IHhECAPFU:p:D:S:R:N:T: --long "${longopts}" -n "$0" -- "$@") if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then usage exit 1 elif [[ ! $@ =~ ^\-.+ ]] || [[ $@ =~ ^\-\-$ ]]; then usage exit 0 fi eval set -- "$opt" while true; do case "${1}" in -N|--venv-name) VENV_NAME="${2}" shift 2 ;; -I|--interactive ) INTERACTIVE="INTERACTIVE" shift echo "Interactive mode ON" ;; -H|-h|--help) usage shift exit 0 ;; -F|--force-yes) FORCE_YES="FORCE_YES" shift ;; -E|--no-venv) NO_VENV="NO_VENV" shift ;; -P|--pgsql) PGSQL="PGSQL" shift ;; -A|--pgsql-auth-trust) PG_TRUST="PG_TRUST" shift ;; -C|--clean-install) CLEAN_INSTALL="CLEAN_INSTALL" shift ;; -U|--pg-user) PG_USER="${2}" shift 2 ;; -D|--pg-database) PG_DATABASE="${2}" shift 2 ;; -T|--devops-tag) DEVOPS_TAG="${2}" shift 2 ;; -p|--pg-password) PG_PASS="${2}" shift 2 ;; -S|--sqlite-database) SQLITE_DB_PATH=$(readlink -f "${2}".sqlite3) shift 2 ;; -L|--install-repo-requirements) REQ_LIST="${2}" shift 2 ;; -- ) shift break ;; * ) break ;; esac done if [ "${INTERACTIVE}" == "INTERACTIVE" -a "${FORCE_YES}" == "FORCE_YES" ]; then echo -e "Impossible to use both interactive and force mods at the same time.
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 1 fi if [ ! -z "${NO_VENV}" -a ! -z "${VENV_NAME}" ]; then echo "Impossible to use both --venv-name and --no-venv at the same time.
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 1 fi if [ -z "${NO_VENV}" -a -z "${VENV_NAME}" ]; then echo "At least --venv-name should be set" sleep 1 exit 1 # echo "Venv-name was not set using default ${VENV_NAME:=$(readlink -f ~/fuel-devops)}" fi if [ ! -z "${PGSQL}" -a ! -z "${SQLITE_DB_PATH}" ]; then echo "Impossible to use both database engines at the same time.
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 1 fi if ! [ "x${PG_TRUST}" != "xPG_TRUST" ]||[ "${PG_USER}" != "" ]||[ "${PG_DATABASE}" != "" ]||[ "${PG_PASS}" != "" ]&&[ "x${PGSQL}" != "xPGSQL" ]; then echo -e "PGSQL option is not enabled.
Exiting." sleep 1 exit 1 fi } #Function determines whether user root or have SUDO permissions get_pass() { if [ $(id -u) -eq 0 ]; then echo -e "You are running script with root permissions, be careful!
" else read -sp "Please enter your SUDO password:" PASSWD sudo -S -l <<< "${PASSWD}" 2>&1 >/dev/null if [ "${?}" -ne 0 ]; then echo -e "Sudo password (${PASSWD}) is incorrect.
Exiting..." exit 1 fi fi } #Function for execution with/without SUDO run() { if [ $(id -u) -eq 0 ]; then /bin/bash -c "${1}" 2>&1 > /dev/null else sudo /bin/bash -c "${1}" 2>&1 >/dev/null fi } check_exit() { if [ "${?}" -ne 0 ]; then echo -e "${1}
Exiting..." sleep 2 exit 1 fi } #Question function which will ask questions. ask() { read -p "${1} [YES/no]: " YESNO while ! $(grep -Eqi '(yes|no)' <<< "${YESNO}"); do echo "Incorrect input please use only [YES/no]: " sleep 1 read -p "${1} [YES/no]: " YESNO done } #Determines which Linux Distro is on the host. where_am_i() { case $(lsb_release -is) in Gentoo*) echo -e "Gentoo Linux Detected.
" pkg_mng=$(which emerge) ;; Ubuntu*) echo -e "Ubuntu Linux detected.
" pkg_mng=$(which apt-get) if [ -z "${pkg_mng}" ]; then alt_pkg_mng=$(which dpkg) fi ;; Debian*) echo -e "Debian Linux detected.
" pkg_mng=$(which apt-get) if [ -z "${pkg_mng}" ]; then alt_pkg_mng=$(which dpkg) fi ;; Fedora*) echo -e "Fedora Linux detected.
" pkg_mng=$(which yum) if [ -z "${pkg_mng}" ]; then alt_pkg_mng=$(which rpm) fi ;; SUSE*) echo -e "Suse Linux detected.
" pkg_mng=$(which zypper) if [ -z "${pkg_mng}" ]; then alt_pkg_mng=$(which rpm) fi ;; *) if [ -s /etc/redhat-release ]; then if $(grep -qo "el7" /proc/version); then echo -e "CentOS 7 detected.
" pkg_mng=$(which yum) if [ -z "${pkg_mng}" ]; then alt_pkg_mng=$(which rpm) fi elif $(grep -qo "el6" /proc/version); then echo -e "CentOS 6 detected.
" pkg_mng=$(which yum) if [ -z "${pkg_mng}" ]; then alt_pkg_mng=$(which rpm) fi else echo "Unknown RedHat distro." pkg_mng=$(which yum) if [ -z "${pkg_mng}" ]; then alt_pkg_mng=$(which rpm) fi if [ -z "${pkg_mng}" -o -z "${alt_pkg_mng}" ]; then echo -e "Couldn't get any package manager.
Exiting" exit 1 fi fi else echo "Unknown Linux Distro!
Exiting..." exit 1 fi ;; esac } create_db_user() { if [[ "$(psql -U postgres -tAc 'SELECT 1 FROM pg_roles WHERE rolname=''${PG_USER}''')" == "1" ]]; then echo -e "User with the name ${PG_USER} already exists.
Exiting..." exit 1 else psql -U postgres -c 'CREATE ROLE '${PG_USER}' PASSWORD ''${PG_PASS}'' LOGIN' fi if ! $(createdb -U postgres ${PG_DATABASE} -O "${PG_USER}"); then echo "database with the name "${PG_DATABASE}" already exists.
Exiting..." exit 1 fi } #Definition of options for install_func(). def_opts() { if [ -z "${DEVOPS_TAG}" ]; then echo "Devops tag doesn't set using master branch ${DEVOPS_TAG:=master}" fi if [ "${PGSQL}" == "PGSQL" ]; then if $(dpkg -l|grep -q postgresql); then echo "PostgreSQL package installed" sleep 1 else if [ "${INTERACTIVE}" == "INTERACTIVE" ]; then ask "PostgreSQL wasn't installed, would you like to install it?" if [[ ${YESNO} == [Yy][Ee][sS] ]]; then echo "Installing PostgreSQL..." sleep 1 run "apt-get install postgresql --yes" check_exit "Something has happened, PostgreSQL wasn't installed." echo -e "Installation of PostgreSQL successfull.
" else echo -e "You've chosen PostgreSQL as backend.
"\ "PostgreSQL is not installed and your answer is "NO".
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 2 fi elif [ "${FORCE_YES}" == "FORCE_YES" ]; then echo "PostgreSQL wasn't installed.
Installing PostgreSQL..." run "apt-get install postgresql --yes" else echo -e "PostgreSQL is not installed.
Exiting..." exit 1 fi fi if [ "${PG_TRUST}" == "PG_TRUST" ]; then echo "Replacing peer auth to trust" sleep 2 run "sed -ir 's/peer/trust/' /etc/postgresql/9.*/main/pg_hba.conf" check_exit "Can't change peer auth to trust in PostgreSQL settings." echo "Restarting PostgreSQL service..." run "service postgresql restart >>/dev/null" check_exit "PostgreSQL wasn't restarted properly." else if [ "${FORCE_YES}" == "FORCE_YES" ]; then echo "Replacing peer auth to trust" run "sed -ir 's/peer/trust/' /etc/postgresql/9.*/main/pg_hba.conf" check_exit "Can't change peer auth to trust in PostgreSQL settings." echo "Restarting PostgreSQL service..." sleep 1 run "service postgresql restart >>/dev/null" check_exit "PostgreSQL wasn't restarted properly." elif (run "grep -q peer /etc/postgresql/9.*/main/pg_hba.conf"); then ask "Would you like to change auth method from "peer" to "trust"?" if [[ ${YESNO} == [Yy][Ee][sS] ]]; then echo "Replacing peer auth to trust" run "sed -ir 's/peer/trust/' /etc/postgresql/9.*/main/pg_hba.conf" check_exit "Can't change peer auth to trust in PostgreSQL settings." echo "Restarting PostgreSQL service..." run "service postgresql restart >>/dev/null" else echo -e "Auth method is peer can't be used.
Exiting..." fi fi fi if [ -z "${PG_USER}" ]; then echo "Postgresql database user wasn't set using default ${PG_USER:=fuel_devops}" fi if [ -z "${PG_PASS}" ]; then echo "Password for user ${PG_USER} wasn't set using default ${PG_PASS:=fuel_devops}" fi if [ -z "${PG_DATABASE}" ];then echo "Name for Postgresql database wasn't set using default ${PG_DATABASE:=fuel_devops}" fi if [ "${CLEAN_INSTALL}" == "CLEAN_INSTALL" ]; then install_func fi else if [ -z "${SQLITE_DB_PATH}" ]; then echo "Sqlite database path wasn't set using default ${SQLITE_DB_PATH:=$(readlink -f ~/devops_${DEVOPS_TAG}.sqlite3)}" if [ "${CLEAN_INSTALL}" == "CLEAN_INSTALL" ]; then install_func elif [ -s "${SQLITE_DB_PATH}" ]; then echo -e "SQLite database (${SQLITE_DB_PATH}) already exists.
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 1 fi fi fi } #Check if hardware virtualization disabled. cpu_virtualization_check() { if $(grep -qom1 "${1}" /proc/cpuinfo); then echo -e "Hardware virtualization enabled in BIOS.
" echo -e "Checking kernel module "kvm_${cpu_type}" loaded or not.
" sleep 1 kvm_kernel_check else echo -e "Hardware virtualization doesn't enabled.
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 1 fi } #Check if KVM kernel module lodaded according to detected CPU(AMD/INTEL). kvm_kernel_check() { if $(lsmod|grep -qom1 "kvm_${cpu_type}"); then echo -e "Kernel module "kvm_${cpu_type}" loaded.
" echo -e "Checking "Nested Paging" enabled or not.
" nested_pagging_check else if [ ${INTERACTIVE} == "INTERACTIVE" ]; then ask "Would you like to load kvm_${cpu_type} module till the reboot?" if [[ ${YESNO} == [Yy][Ee][sS] ]]; then run "/sbin/modprobe kvm_${cpu_type}" check_exit "Something has happened while loading kernel module kvm_${cpu_type}." fi elif [ "${FORCE_YES}" == "FORCE_YES" ]; then echo "TBD force-yes for kvm_kernel_check" run "/sbin/modprobe kvm_${cpu_type}" check_exit "Something has happened while loading kernel module kvm_${cpu_type}." else echo -e "Kernel Module "kvm_${cpu_type}" isn't loaded.
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 1 fi fi } #Check whether nested pagging enabled of not. nested_pagging_check() { if $(grep -q "^Y$" "/sys/module/kvm_${cpu_type}/parameters/nested"); then echo -e "Nested pagging is enabled.
" ip_filters else echo -e "Nested Pagging is not enabled.
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 1 fi } #Check whether bridge filtration rules enbled in kernel or not. ip_filters() { ORIG_IFS="${IFS}" IFS=$'
' for filter in $(sysctl -a 2>&1|grep -P "net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-(arp|ip|ip6)tables"); do if [ "${filter: -1}" == "1" ]; then echo "${filter:26: -4} filter is enabled" #Check if interactive mode on. if [ "${INTERACTIVE}" == "INTERACTIVE" ]; then ask "Would you like to permanently deactivate ${filter:26: -4} filter?" if [[ ${YESNO} == [Yy][Ee][sS] ]]; then if ! $(grep -q "${filter:: -1}0" "/etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf"); then echo "Filter ${filter:26: -4} will be disabled" run "echo ${filter:: -1}0 >> /etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf" else echo -e "${filter:: -1}0 already in /etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf
" # echo "Will apply changes in the end" fi fi elif [ "${FORCE_YES}" == "FORCE_YES" ]; then echo "TBD for force ip_filters" if ! $(grep -q "${filter:: -1}0" "/etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf"); then echo "Filter ${filter:26: -4} will be disabled" run "echo ${filter:: -1}0 >> /etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf" check_exit "Something has happened while addind ${filter:26: -4} to /etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf." else echo -e "${filter:: -1}0 already in /etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf
" echo "Will apply changes in the end" fi fi else echo "filter ${filter:26 -4} not enabled" disabled_filters+="${filter:26: -4}
" fi done if [ -s /etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf ]&&[ $(echo -e "${disabled_filters}" |wc -l) -lt "4" ]; then echo -e "Applying changes to the kernel.
" run "sysctl -p /etc/sysctl.d/net-bridge-filters.conf" fi IFS="${ORIG_IFS}" } #Check if all necessary packages are installed. check_packages() { OLD_IFS="${IFS}" IFS="," if [ "${N}" == "" ]; then run "apt-get update" N+="1" fi for package in ${1}; do # where_am_i # case if $(apt-cache policy ${package}|grep -q "Installed: (none)"); then echo "Package ${package} doesn't installed" sleep 1 instalation_packages+="${package} " else echo -e "Package ${package} is already installed.
" sleep 1 fi done if [ "${INTERACTIVE}" == "INTERACTIVE" -a -n "${instalation_packages}" ]; then ask "Would you like to install followig package\(s\): [ ${instalation_packages}]" if [[ "${YESNO}" == [Yy][Ee][Ss] ]]; then run "apt-get install --yes ${instalation_packages}" fi elif [ -n "${instalation_packages}" ]; then if [ "${FORCE_YES}" == "FORCE_YES" ]; then echo "TBD force-yes for check_packages" run "apt-get install --yes ${instalation_packages}" check_exit "Something has happened while installing necessary packages
[ ${instalation_packages}]." else echo -e "Following pakage\(s\) are not installed [ ${instalation_packages}].
Exiting..." sleep 1 exit 1 fi fi IFS="${OLD_IFS}" } #Body of script which check what CPU are in use. cpu_check() { case $(awk '/vendor_id/ {print $3}' /proc/cpuinfo|sort -u) in GenuineIntel*) cpu_type="intel" cpu_virtualization_check "vmx" check_packages "${package_list}" unset instalation_packages ;; AuthenticAMD*) cpu_type="amd" cpu_virtualization_check "svm" check_packages "${package_list}" unset instalation_packages ;; *) echo -e "Unknown CPU vendor.
Exiting..." sleep 2 exit 1 ;; esac } devops_env_vars() { if [ ! -z "${SQLITE_DB_PATH}" ]; then echo "export DEVOPS_DB_ENGINE='django.db.backends.sqlite3'" >> "${1}" echo "export DEVOPS_DB_NAME="${SQLITE_DB_PATH}"" >> "${1}" # Ability to unset custom variables to avoid confusion with variables in case of manual check of job results. if [[ "${1}" == *"/bin/activate" ]]; then sed -i "s/\(unset VIRTUAL_ENV\)/\1 DEVOPS_DB_ENGINE DEVOPS_DB_NAME/" "${1}" fi else echo "export DEVOPS_DB_ENGINE='django.db.backends.postgresql_psycopg2'" >> "${1}" echo "export DEVOPS_DB_NAME="${PG_DATABASE}"" >> "${1}" echo "export DEVOPS_DB_USER="${PG_USER}"" >> "${1}" echo "export DEVOPS_DB_PASSWORD="${PG_PASS}"" >> "${1}" # Ability to unset custom variables to avoid confusion with variables in case of manual check of job results. if [[ "${1}" == *"/bin/activate" ]]; then sed -i "s/\(unset VIRTUAL_ENV\)/\1 DEVOPS_DB_ENGINE DEVOPS_DB_NAME DEVOPS_DB_PASSWORD DEVOPS_DB_USER/" "${1}" fi fi source "${1}" /bin/rm -rf ./fuel-devops-source git clone https://github.com/openstack/fuel-devops ./fuel-devops-source check_exit "Something has happened while cloning fuel-devops." cd ./fuel-devops-source if [ "${DEVOPS_TAG}" == "master" ]; then pip install ./ --upgrade ./manage.py migrate else git checkout tags/"${DEVOPS_TAG}" pip install ./ --upgrade django-admin.py syncdb --settings=devops.settings django-admin.py migrate devops --settings=devops.settings fi } #Function which will install Devops and if set install-repo-requirements(TBD) install_func() { if [ "${CLEAN_INSTALL}" == "CLEAN_INSTALL" ]; then if [ ! -z "${PGSQL}" ]; then if [ ! -z "${PG_DATABASE}" ] && $(psql -Upostgres -lqAt|grep -Eq "^${PG_DATABASE}\|"); then echo -e "Dropping existing database with the name "${PG_DATABASE}"." dropdb -U postgres "${PG_DATABASE}" 2>&1 >/dev/null check_exit "Database wasn't terminated." fi if [[ "$(psql -U postgres -tAc 'SELECT 1 FROM pg_roles WHERE rolname=''${PG_USER}''')" == "1" ]]; then echo -e "User with the name ${PG_USER} exists.
Terminating ${PG_USER}..." dropuser -U postgres "${PG_USER}" check_exit "User wasn't terminated." fi else /bin/rm -f "${SQLITE_DB_PATH}" fi if [ -n "${VENV_NAME}" ]; then source "${VENV_NAME}/bin/activate" if $(pip freeze|grep -q fuel-devops);then pip uninstall -y fuel-devops check_exit "Something has hapenned while uninstalling devops" else echo -e "No fuel-devops was found, continue with the fresh installation." fi deactivate elif [ ! -z "${NO_VEVN}" ]; then if $(pip freeze|grep -q fuel-devops); then run "pip uninstall -y fuel-devops" check_exit "Something has hapenned while uninstalling devops" else echo -e "No fuel-devops was found, continue with the fresh installation." fi fi fi if [ -n "${VENV_NAME}" ]; then check_packages "${venv_packs}" unset instalation_packages if [ ! -z "${PGSQL}" ]; then create_db_user fi virtualenv "${VENV_NAME}" cd "${VENV_NAME}" devops_env_vars "${VENV_NAME}/bin/activate" else if [ ! -z "${PGSQL}" ]; then create_db_user fi devops_env_vars "~/.bashrc_devops" fi } opts $@ if [[ "${PASSWD}" == "" ]]; then get_pass fi cpu_check def_opts if [ -z ${CLEAN_INSTALL} ]; then install_func fi

commit_message:
Remove _add_system_params

_add_system_params sets storlet parameters in a request instance,
but these parameters are never used.
This patch removes that unneccesory setting.

Change-Id: I4b018bc6fd31ee24250ab44d58ee976a45afc626

commit_message:
Retire the repository

This repository was used to develop upgrade Fuel admin
node scripts. At the moment all upgrade related stuff
is being developed in fuel-octane.

added_lines: def test_update_logging_resource_with_firewall_log(self): expected = {'name': NEW_LOG_RES_NAME, 'description': NEW_LOG_RES_DESC, 'enabled': ENABLED_TRUE} with self.logging_resource() as log_res, \ self.firewall_log(log_res['logging_resource']['id'], firewall_id=self._fw_id1): data = {'logging_resource': {'name': NEW_LOG_RES_NAME, 'description': NEW_LOG_RES_DESC, 'enabled': ENABLED_TRUE}} req = self.new_update_request('logging/logging_resources', data, log_res['logging_resource']['id']) res = self.deserialize(self.fmt, req.get_response(self.ext_api)) self.assertDictSupersetOf(expected, res['logging_resource'])

commit_message:
Delete unused cert_group variable

'cert_group=root' in make-cert*.sh isn't used anywhere.
so let's remove it.

Change-Id: I3c4f726ec6fc1ba5bb02f5615f9e0999d6ea02cb
